In 2003, the American Cancer Society decided studies didn't conclusively support that breast self-examinations, or BSCs, reduce the number of deaths from breast cancer.

The society's spokesperson, Heather Logan, explains why.

What's different about the recommendations today is that we're transitioning away from the very prescriptive, rigorous approach to breast self exam that has to be done in a very certain way at a very specific time of the month on a regular basis towards breast health awareness.
Logan says the society's doctors feel the benefits of BSCs aren't clear, whereas some of the drawbacks are.
One is the tendency of some women to find every little change, even normal ones, alarming.
That leads to additional tests and biopsies to make sure everything's okay.

And, says Logan, there's another drawback doctors find even more worrisome.
